head.title: POSTINGS: Small Co-ops and Condos; Capping the Assessments

hedline.hl1: POSTINGS: Small Co-ops and Condos; Capping the Assessments

block.p: Small co-ops and condominiums have long asserted that when it comes to the city's property-tax policies, they were burdened with an unfair disadvantage.

"On one hand, the law required that we be assessed as if we were rental buildings," said Lawrence H. McGaughey, an attorney and secretary of the 2-10 Units Association, a group formed two years ago to press for property-tax reform, "but at the same time we did not have the protection of the assessment cap that small rental buildings have."
Small co-ops and condominiums have long asserted that when it comes to the city's property-tax policies, they were burdened with an unfair disadvantage.

"On one hand, the law required that we be assessed as if we were rental buildings," said Lawrence H. McGaughey, an attorney and secretary of the 2-10 Units Association, a group formed two years ago to press for property-tax reform, "but at the same time we did not have the protection of the assessment cap that small rental buildings have."

The group's lobbying efforts have paid off. Late last month, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo signed a bill that brings small co-ops and condominiums into the category of residences -- one-, two- and three-family homes and rental buildings with from four to 10 units -- that have annual caps of 6 to 8 percent on their tax assessment increases. The new law puts an 8 percent cap on the assessment increase for co-ops and condominiums with fewer than than 11 units.
The buildings will be reassessed on the new basis, beginning with the 1993-1994 tax year. But the measure does not provide for tax refunds based on higher assessments in previous years.
